content:
The Clerk of the House of Commons is an impartial and non-partisan official who is required to serve the House of Commons as a whole, rather than any particular political party or interest group. Moreover, the Clerk is subject to strict ethical and professional standards that prohibit them from engaging in any partisan or lobbying activities.

As a highly respected and experienced professional, the Clerk is expected to act with the utmost integrity and discretion in their role. Any allegations of impropriety, bias or conflict of interest would be taken very seriously by Parliament and could result in a full investigation by the relevant authorities.

Overall, we can have confidence in the impartiality of the Clerk of the House of Commons, who plays a vital role in ensuring that the legislative process is conducted in a fair and transparent manner, and in accordance with the rules and procedures of Parliament.
